docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans, the troubled managed care company, disclosed yesterday that it had obtained $100 million in short-term financing and that it was actively pursuing other sources of capital. The company received a bridge loan on Friday from an affiliate of the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, according to a filing Oxford made with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Under the agreement, Oxford could obtain an additional $100 million in cash. Oxford said it intended to pay off the loan, and any additional money that it borrowed, ''with the proceeds of more permanent financing during 1998.'' The filing said the money would be used to increase the capital of the company's H.M.O. operations, pay expenses related to this financing and for general corporate purposes. A company spokeswoman would not elaborate.

headline.main: For Oxford, Talks and a $100 Million Loan

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans has obtained $100 million in short-term financing and will actively pursue other sources of capital; company is said to be talking wiht several potential sources of financing, including buyout firms Texas Pacific Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co, but such a deal does not appear to be imminent (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Three months after proposing a basic health care plan for up to 420,000 uninsured children of low-income families, Gov. George E. Pataki reversed course today and called for a far broader plan that would provide benefits for dental, vision, hearing and mental health care. The proposal, which children's advocates say would be one of the most generous publicly financed health programs in the nation, needs the approval of the State Legislature and Federal officials. And Mr. Pataki is sure to encounter a fight from Democrats in the Legislature who want to expand the program even further to cover hundreds of thousands more uninsured children from families with somewhat higher incomes.

headline.main: Pataki Broadens Health Plan for Children

docs.abstract: Gov George E Pataki, three months after proposing basic health care plan for up to 420,000 uninsured children of low-income families, reverses course and calls for far broader plan that would provide benefits for dental, vision, hearing and mental health care; proposal, which children's advocates say would be one of most generous publicly financed health programs in nation, needs approval of State Legislature and Federal officials; Pataki's proposal would not require any state money, but would be financed from New York's share of $24 billion appropriated by Congress last year to pay for children's health care (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten weeks ago while discussing the Olympic Games, United States Coach Ron Wilson was asked whether Brian Leetch would be his captain. Without committing himself, Wilson recalled the 1996 World Cup, which the United States won. ''He was the captain of the World Cup team,'' Wilson said of Leetch, the attacking defenseman of the Rangers. ''It would be hard not to go with the same people. He did a great job.''

headline.main: 'C' Stands for Chelios And for U.S. Captain
headline.kicker: THE XVIII WINTER GAMES: ICE HOCKEY

docs.abstract: US hockey Coach Ron Wilson names Chris Chelios of Chicago Blackhawks captain of team for its first Olympic game against Sweden (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Montefiore Medical Center has teamed up with a for-profit company in a $100 million deal to open a string of 24-hour-a-day clinics devoted to cancer care and treatment of H.I.V. and AIDS in the New York metropolitan region. Analysts said the partnership reflected a nationwide move toward clinics focused on specific diseases and toward innovative attempts by nonprofit hospitals to find new sources of capital to grow.

headline.main: Region to Get Clinics Giving Specialty Care

docs.abstract: Montefiore Medical Center (NYC) has teamed up with Bentley Health Care, for-profit company, in a $100 million deal to open string of 24-hour-a-day clinics devoted to cancer care and treatment of HIV and AIDS in New York metropolitan region; analysts say that partnership reflects nationwide move toward clinics focused on specific diseases and toward innovating attempts by nonprofit hospitals to find new sources of capital to grow (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: District Council 37, the coalition representing 120,000 New York City municipal workers, has been plunged into what some labor leaders are calling its worst crisis ever because prosecutors are investigating 7 of its 56 union locals and because a well-known president of one of its locals has been suspended. Many union members complained last week about lax ethics and financial controls after Charles Hughes, president of the local representing 22,000 school crossing guards and cafeteria workers, was suspended for helping to drive his local $8 million into debt. Mr. Hughes, who has denied any wrongdoing, is also being investigated for taking $800,000 in what union leaders said were unusual expense reimbursements.

headline.main: New York Municipal Union Grapples With Deep Trouble

docs.abstract: District Council 37, part of American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, is experiencing probably worst crisis ever as prosecutors press investigation of seven of its 56 union locals and because of suspension of well-known president, Charles Hughes; crisis is embarrassing blow to Mayor Rudolph Giuliani since Hughes and Stanley Hill, district council's embattled executive director, are among his closest and most enthusiastic labor allies; suspension of Hughes follows complaints of lax ethics and financial controls after he allegedly helped drive local, which represents 22,000 school crossing guards, $8 million into debt; Hughes, who has denied wrongdoing, is also being investigated for allegedly taking $800,000 in unusual expense reimbursements; prosecutors are investigating allegations that officials at several locals accepted kickbacks; scandals have raised questions about Hill's stewardship by many union members, who say he has failed to set tough tone warning leaders of 56 locals against lining their pockets; photo (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Kevin Masaquiza was born last Wednesday in a big double bed, in a room with glorious views of the East River. Flower-flecked paper covered the walls, which were decorated with bright framed pictures. In the corner of the room was a glass-enclosed Jacuzzi, where his mother could have relaxed while she was in labor. By the looks of it, Ines Masaquiza could have been delivering her second son in a luxury Manhattan hotel. In fact, Kevin's mother, a sewing-machine operator, was the first woman to give birth in Bellevue Hospital Center's new birthing center, which opens officially tomorrow.

headline.main: At Bellevue, Luring Back New Mothers With Luxury

docs.abstract: Bellevue Hospital Center's luxurious new birthing center opens officially on Feb 9; center is part of multimillion-dollar attempt to reverse trend that is troubling to public hospitals in New York City: defection of low-income, Medicaid-insured pregnant women to private hospitals that once shunned them; photo of Ines Masaquiza, first woman to give birth in new center (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For some, gambling can become an addiction. ''Gambling hasn't been so available in the past,'' said Dr. Sheila Blume, a psychiatrist at South Oaks Hospital in Amityville who specializes in addictions. ''Now, with casinos within reach, people who have never really experienced much gambling besides a church bingo game are getting exposed to a different kind of gambling which is exciting. It's this excitement they seem to get hooked on.'' Some people use gambling to deal with other problems like loneliness, chronic pain, terminal illnesses or financial woes.

headline.main: For the Gambling Elderly, Help in Fighting Addiction

docs.abstract: South Oaks Hospital psychiatrist Dr Sheila Blume comments on help available to elderly Long Islanders who have gambling addictions (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: SINCE its entry into the Long Island industrial market a year ago with the purchase of a 2.7-million-square-foot industrial portfolio owned by Lazarus Burman Associates of Syosset, First Industrial Realty Trust of Chicago has acquired 1.2 million additional square feet in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. ''We have a lot more in the pipeline and expect to add two to three million square feet more by the end of the year,'' said Jeff Schwartzberg, senior investment officer for First Industrial's northeast regional office in Syosset, of which Jan Burman is the senior regional director.

headline.main: In the Region/Long Island; REITs Moving More Aggressively Into the Market
